content: this episode I show you how he turned a dollar store toy into a cool patinas
bronze statue you guys are like me you're always looking for cool little
pieces of train you can build to throw on your table to make things a little
bit more interesting say your players are exploring an old graveyard
instead of ruin maybe an abandoned town something that you can put on the table
that really enhances the ambience is a mysterious statue and there's no better
way to do it then with a dollar store toy modified painted in such a way to
look like an old bronze patina'd statue it's a really easy project to make like
I said one dollar toy from the dollar store a nail spray paint a little scrap
styrofoam whatever you got some craft paint really it doesn't get much cheaper
and easier than this so if you want to have something that looks like this on
your table and are willing to spend no half an hour making it I'll show you how
I did it Steve start the pictures okay so this
thing started out as this little Maleficent toy from the dollar store
specifically from Dollar Tree they've got I think it's like four different
villains in this line but the other ones don't I don't really think would work
well for statue but this one with a little bit of modification definitely
looks the part out of the package there are a few small problems with it that
need to be addressed before moving forward the first I did not like the
look of this crow or Raven that's perched on her shoulder so I just took
my exacto knife and cut that right off the second problem is her staff so
there's two things about it one it has this ugly square bit of support between
her clothing and the staff and the second is that it is made of a very soft
kind of rubbery plastic that bends a lot I wanted it to be nice and rigid so I
actually just went ahead and cut that entire staff right out including the
support this plastics so easy to cut with a blade that you can cut things off
and blend it and you won't even notice once I had the staff cut off I needed
something to replace it with so I just looked through my hardware and I found a
spiral nail our Doc's nail that was the right diameter and the right length and
the actual spiral of the nail I think actually looks a bit better than just a
plain smooth one so I went with that and under her hand I just kind of dug in a
little point for the point of the nail to stick into you used a bit of super
glue and glued it in place the bottom of it however needed something to secure
too because being blue just at the point of the nail definitely wasn't enough so
if you're the best way to do this was actually to create a bit of a base for
the whole statue and that would give something for the head of the nail to
glue to so I just took a bit of scrap styrofoam and cut it out to the shape of
the bottom of her kind of case there including a little Jutta
for this nail and I just hot glued everything in place and then made sure
to also super glue the edge of the nail head to the bottom of the toy this made
everything nice and secure now I wanted to spray-paint this whole thing because
when you're dealing with these cheap Chinese plastic toys the plastics that
they're made out of vary greatly and they can be really problematic for
painting I personally found that the Krylon two-in-one paint and primer tends
to stick well to this type of plastic and dries
get tacky like some of them do so that's what I used to spray-paint this whole
thing black and give me a fresh flat start to put my acrylic paints on but if
I was going to be spray-painting it that meant that the styrofoam on the bottom
the base that I made would melt so what I actually did was I just gave it a
quick protective coating and on this one I happen to use a mix of drywall joint
compound and glue and black paint it makes styrofoam rock hard and there's no
risk of melting with this method you could just get away with a coat or two a
PVA glue but when you're doing that sort of thing I recommend mixing in some
black paint or something just so you can see if you've missed anything but I
always keep some of this sludge of grade filler around for this purpose and it
works really well so coated the entire styrofoam area let
that dry and once it was dry I just spray painted the whole thing flat black
after that I was ready to start actually doing the real paint job on this so it's
just a couple coats of different colors the base coat is a folk art metallic
called chocolate brown and this basically looks like a really dark
bronze so even when I'm painting metallics I kind of do it in the same
method I would if I was doing it in non metallics like say this was would start
with a darker brown and move progressively up to lighter shades so I
find that this chocolate brown metallic is a nice base coat when working with
bronze or copper and I completely cover the whole thing make sure to get in all
the crevices with it once that was dry I moved on to the actual bronze and of all
the craft paints I found this has the best kind of bronze color
it's by craft smart it's one of their premium colors I mean not when they say
premium it's still premium craft paint still in cost like two or three bucks
but it has a really strong pigment to it a lot of metallics it covers really
nicely and I really like the particular color of it because it has that really
coppery undertone to the bronze rather than more of a brown so I gave the whole
thing a coat in that and I say I probably gave it a 90% coverage you know
not making sure to get in all the little cracks and crevices and this coat is
what gives it it's real nice bronze shine but of course this looks like a
brand new Statue and if that's what you're going for stay in a temple that's
indoors and induce you can go from this step straight into the washes and call
it a day but if you want it to have that kind of patinas look like I did you want
to look like it's been outside in the rain for many many years you're going to
want to give it that green bronze patina there are I'm sure paint ready-made that
you can buy for this I know the whole view miniature painting companies have
their own patina kind of colors but if you want to achieve it really cheaply
and easily with all my experimenting I found that these two colors mixed
together give you a perfect patina so both our craft smart colors one is
called ocean breeze and one is called apple tart when you're making this color
you need it to have a mix of blue and green but the blue has to be kind of
like an aqua or turquoise kind of blue and the green has to be like a vibrant
almost almost neon green so mix these two together it's almost 50/50 half and
a half but just do it by eye and and you should recognize the color pull up some
reference photos of bronze statues and go from there so when you mix that
together then you're going to want to go and cover the statute here when I when I
paint this I use kind of like a dabbing method with my brush and I make sure
only to get all the outermost flat surfaces I don't try to put this into
the crevasses because you want some of that bronze still showing through
otherwise it just looks like a green statue and if you look at reference
photos they're only there usually is a decent amount of bronze still showing
through and it seems that this patina happens on the outer most most weathered
surfaces so if you're kind of doing this like a dry brush getting it on those
surfaces without getting into the cracks but on the big open areas like on the
front of her outfit you want to do it like a kind of stipple dab method and
you can use a brush for this or you can use a small sponge at that point it
begins to look the part but it still looks too clean and too fresh so from
there I gave it a couple washes and of course you can check my episode on black
how to make a simple black wash I'm using a few different colored washes
here but the method is exactly the same I'm starting off with a brown wash and I
have found that I am trying to move away from putting my washes on with a brush I
want it to hit the piece naturally and let gravity kind of do its job since I
don't have an airbrush and I'm guessing a lot of you don't have an airbrush grab
some of these like one dollar spray bottles from the dollar store you get
like a three pack or a buck and put your washes in there it's a nice way to just
be able to like squirt things on naturally it's a little bit messy
of course but you know big paper down or whatever but I found it's really nice
way to apply Washington so first was a brown wash completely
soaked this thing and it lets that gouache mostly dry up but I didn't wait
till it's completely dry before moving on and giving it a coat of a black wash
this really gets in those creases and makes it look grimy and dirty and last
just to give it that look like it had been sitting in an outdoor damp location
I gave it a subtle green wash it doesn't show through obviously on the green
paint job but it is there and it does make things look a little bit more grimy
and that's basically it as soon as that is all done and dried it's ready for the
table if you want you can give the whole thing a coating in Minwax polyurethane
in a satin it will really seal everything in I didn't really worry
about on this piece because it's something that will hit the table only
once in a while it's not going to see heavy gameplay but if you transport your
stuff or you're doing a bunch of stuff that's going to see a lot of play
hitting it with that polyurethane would not be a bad idea alright guys I hope
you found this video useful if you did hit that like button and drop me a
